required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Carbidopa/Levodopa/Entacapone in Patients With Parkinson's Disease Requiring Initiation of Levodopa Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: A Long Term, Double-blind, Randomized, Parallel-group, Carbidopa/Levodopa Controlled, Multi-center Study to Evaluate the Effect of Carbidopa/Levodopa/Entacapone in Patients With Parkinson's Disease Requiring Initiation of Levodopa Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: The CELC200A2401 study has been designed in order to evaluate the hypothesis that administering the combination carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone at the time that levodopa therapy is initiated results in a decrease in the risk of the development of motor complications for patients with Parkinson's disease.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Time to First Occurrence of Dyskinesia
primary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment duration for an individual patient varied between a minimum of 134 weeks for those patients recruited last and a maximum of 208 weeks for those patients recruited first
primary_outcome.description: Dyskinesia was assessed by a blinded rater at each visit. Time to dyskinesia was defined as the visit at which the rater first answered "yes" to the following question: "In your opinion, does this patient have dyskinesia?" Time to dyskinesia was estimated by Kaplan-Meier product limit estimate that takes into consideration patients who did not experience dyskinesia by censoring them at the end of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Total Score (Parts II and III)
secondary_outcome.description: The UPDRS is a standardized assessment scale used to measure the patient's disease state. It was to be completed by a blinded rater. There are 6 parts to the UPDRS. Part II (items 5-17; total score 0-52 units on the scale) measures the patient's activities of daily living and part III (items 18-31; total score 0-56 units on the scale) measures the motor function of the patient. The total score ranges from 0 to 108 units on the scale. A higher score indicates greater disability. A negative change score indicates improvement.

Wearing-off is defined as a perception of loss of mobility or dexterity, usually taking place gradually over minutes (up to an hour) and usually bearing a close temporal relationship to the timing of anti-parkinsonian medications; it does not include early-morning akinesia. To ascertain its occurrence, a blinded rater questioned the patient as to whether he/she had noticed that the benefits of the study drug were wearing-off.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Occurrence of Wearing-off
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to end of study (134-208 weeks of treatment)
secondary_outcome.description: Wearing off is defined as a perception of loss of mobility or dexterity, usually taking place gradually over minutes (up to an hour) and usually bearing a close temporal relationship to the timing of anti-parkinsonian medications; it does not include early-morning akinesia. To ascertain its occurrence, a blinded rater questioned the patient whether he/she had noticed that the benefits of the study drug wear-off. A motor complications and patient questionnaire card were provided to assist the blinded rater in determining whether a patient had experienced wearing-off.

Dyskinesia was assessed by a blinded rater at each visit. Time to dyskinesia was defined as the visit at which the rater first answered "yes" to the following question: "In your opinion, does this patient have dyskinesia?"

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Health-related Quality of Life Assessed Using the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39)
secondary_outcome.description: The PDQ-39 instrument is used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The total score can range from 39 to 190. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.

arm_group.description: Patients received Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone tablets. The study was designed as a flexible dose trial (200-1000 mg/day levodopa). The target dose was 400 mg/day levodopa administered orally as 4 equal doses 4 times a day with 3.5-hour dosing intervals for a treatment period of 134 to 208 weeks.

Patients received Immediate release carbidopa/levodopa tablets. The study was designed as a flexible dose trial (200-1000 mg/day levodopa). The target dose was 400 mg/day levodopa administered orally as 4 equal doses 4 times a day with 3.5-hour dosing intervals for a treatment period of 134 to 208 weeks.

intervention.description: Immediate release carbidopa/levodopa 12.5/50 mg and 25/100 mg capsules.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson's disease
- Diagnosis of Parkinson's disease for no more than 5 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- History, signs, or symptoms of atypical or secondary parkinsonism
- Presence at baseline of drug-related wearing-off symptoms, dyskinesia or other motor complications
- Levodopa exposure of more than 30 days or anytime within 8 weeks prior to visit 1
Other inclusion/exclusion criteria applied to this study.

facility.name: Keck School of Medicine, Division of Movement Disorders
Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorder Center
Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorder Center of Albany Medical
Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorders Center of Long Island
Duke University Medical Center Movement Disorders Center
University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas
Baylor College of Medicine, Parkinson's Disease Center
Wisconsin Institute for Neurologic and Sleep Disorders

participants_list.participants: One patient from each group discontinued without receiving a single dose of study drug.
Plus 1 death in the carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone group within 30 days of treatment discontinuation
Plus 1 death in the carbidopa/levodopa group within 30 days of treatment discontinuation

measure.title: Age
measure.description: Baseline numbers represent the Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Of the 747 randomized patients, one patient in each group discontinued the study without receiving a single dose of study drug and was excluded from the ITT population.

outcome.title: Time to First Occurrence of Dyskinesia
outcome.description: Dyskinesia was assessed by a blinded rater at each visit. Time to dyskinesia was defined as the visit at which the rater first answered “yes” to the following question: “In your opinion, does this patient have dyskinesia?” Time to dyskinesia was estimated by Kaplan-Meier product limit estimate that takes into consideration patients who did not experience dyskinesia by censoring them at the end of the study.
outcome.time_frame: Treatment duration for an individual patient varied between a minimum of 134 weeks for those patients recruited last and a maximum of 208 weeks for those patients recruited first
outcome.population: The intent to treat (ITT) population consisted of all patients randomized who received at least one dose of study drug. Following the ITT principle, patients were analyzed according to the treatment they were assigned at randomization.

outcome.description: Wearing-off is defined as a perception of loss of mobility or dexterity, usually taking place gradually over minutes (up to an hour) and usually bearing a close temporal relationship to the timing of anti-parkinsonian medications; it does not include early-morning akinesia. outcome.population: The intent to treat (ITT) population consisted of all patients randomized who received at least one dose of study drug. Subjects who discontinued treatment before 134 weeks without wearing-off were excluded.

measure.description: Wearing off is defined as a perception of loss of mobility or dexterity, usually taking place gradually over minutes (up to an hour) and usually bearing a close temporal relationship to the timing of anti-parkinsonian medications; it does not include early-morning akinesia. To ascertain its occurrence, a blinded rater questioned the patient whether he/she had noticed that the benefits of the study drug wear-off. outcome.title: Occurrence of Dyskinesia
outcome.description: Dyskinesia was assessed by a blinded rater at each visit. Time to dyskinesia was defined as the visit at which the rater first answered “yes” to the following question: “In your opinion, does this patient have dyskinesia?”
outcome.population: The intent to treat (ITT) population consisted of all patients randomized who received at least one dose of study drug. measure.title: Occurrence of Dyskinesia

Following the ITT principle, patients were analyzed according to the treatment they were assigned at randomization. Subjects who discontinued from treatment before 134 weeks without dyskinesia were excluded.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Health-related Quality of Life Assessed Using the 39-item Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire (PDQ-39)
outcome.description: The PDQ-39 instrument is used to assess quality of life in individuals with Parkinson’s disease. The questionnaire provides scores on eight scales: Mobility, activities of daily living, emotions, stigma, social support, cognition, communication, and bodily discomfort. Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The total score can range from 39 to 190. A lower score indicates better quality of life. A negative change score indicates an improvement.
outcome.population: The intent to treat (ITT) population consisted of all patients randomized who received at least one dose of study drug. Following the ITT principle, patients were analyzed according to the treatment they were assigned at randomization.

Questions are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 3 (sometimes) to 5 (always). The total score can range from 39 to 190. A lower score indicates better quality of life. category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The terms and conditions of Novartis' agreements with its investigators may vary. However, Novartis does not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Any publications from a single-site are postponed until the publication of the pooled data (i.e., data from all sites) in the clinical trial.
